title: Castle Ashby Walks

images.title: Rob Farrow / Castle Ashby - "The Castle"
images.caption: "The Castle" at Castle Ashby is a collection of fine buildings and gardens dating back to the C14th. There are numerous listed components

images.title: Gordon Cragg / Ornamental Gates, Castle Ashby, Northamptonshire
images.caption: Ornamental Gates.

images.title: Kokai / Grendon Quarter Pond
images.caption: Grendon Quarter Pond. A largish, long lake, part of the Grendon Lakes system which resulted from quarrying.

images.title: Nigel Stickells / Parkhill Farm, Castle Ashby
images.caption: Parkhill Farm is on the edge of the Castle Ashby estate. The farm now includes stables - Parkhill Livery - with the fields in the foreground, and off camera to the right, divided into many paddocks.

images.title: Kokai, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Castle Ashby Orangery

images.title: Kokai / Terracotta Bridge and Dam
images.caption: Terracotta Bridge and Dam. This is the work of leading C18th Landscape designer Lancelot 'Capability' Brown.

description: This circular walk takes you around the village of Castle Ashby and its associated gardens. The walk starts from the car park at the Castle Ashby House and Gardens which are the seat of the Marquess of Northampton. There's 35 acres to explore with Italian Gardens, an Orangery, an Arboretum and a a series of pretty ponds. There's also a Menagerie with a number of animals including meerkats, a giant tortoise, a miniature pony, pigs, goats and rabbits. You can then enjoy a stroll around the village which was set up to service the needs of the House. There's also a footpath you could follow up to Grendon and then stroll down to the Grendon Ponds.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The on site Walled Garden Tea Room is a fine place to enjoy some post walk refreshment. If the weather is good you can sit outside on the lovely terrace. If you prefer a pub lunch then you could head to the Falcon Hotel in the village. It's a historic place dating back to 1594 when it was previously a Coaching Inn. There's even a designated private nature walk if you wish to stretch your legs further. You can find them at postcode NN7 1LF for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: Inside the grounds dogs on leads are permitted and can be off lead in the arboretum area.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Head a couple of miles north of the castle and you will come to the Nene Way. There some nice trails here along the river towards the Grendon Lakes complex. Here you'll find 12 lakes, 2 of which are devoted to watersports the remaining 10 making up some of the finest fishing water in the area. There is a popular paintball site site here too. If you were to follow the Nene Way west it would take you into Northampton where you could pick up the Grand Union Canal on the Northampton Canal Walk. There's also some peaceful woodland trails in the nearby Salcey Forest and on the popular Harlestone Firs Forest Walk. A few miles south there's Emberton Country Park where there are more nice waterside trails and lots of wildlife to see. For more walking ideas in the area see the Northamptonshire Walks page.

display_address: Chadstone, Castle Ashby, West Northamptonshire, England, NN7 1LF, United Kingdom
